body: In the quest to find the perfect middle school for her 10-year-old daughter, Aimée Margolis has zig-zagged across Manhattan for 11 school visits, grilled pre-teenagers at a school fair on music classes and the preferred attire at dances, and compiled a dog-eared folder full of notes. Then there is the bathroom test. After a 90-minute tour of the
title: All's Fair in Middle School Scramble, Even Panic

body: Correction Appended 'LATKES AND APPLESAUCE' Hanukkah may be celebrated for eight full nights and have an army of heroes in its history, but the number of annual stage extravaganzas devoted to it is nowhere near as robust. No one goes to Radio City Music Hall for a spectacular about the Festival of Lights. Sean Hartley has filled that gap, albeit on
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: FOR CHILDREN 'BABES IN TOYLAND' (Saturday) The Little Orchestra Society is celebrating the 150th birthday of this holiday classic with an appropriate present: the world premiere of a new version, featuring an updated book and lyrics and additional toys, including an evil, Transformers-style robot. Craig Shermin has adapted the story, making Toyland
title: Spare Times

body: IN September, Cathy DeVore, a real estate agent in Larchmont, N.Y., whose business has been at a standstill lately, began taking gradual steps to lay off her longtime nanny and housekeeper. Aware that the woman supports a son, a mother, and a niece in Dominica, and worried for their well-being, Mrs. DeVore wanted to make sure her employee found
title: Trickledown Downsizing

body: Since 2000, the number of young children living in parts of Lower Manhattan has nearly doubled. The poverty rate declined in all but one New York City neighborhood. A majority of Bronx residents are Hispanic. And the number of white people living in Harlem more than tripled, helping to drive up median household income there by nearly 20 percent --
title: City Growing More Diverse, Census Finds

body: LONG ISLAND COLLEGE HOSPITAL has stood at the northwestern corner of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, overlooking the harbor for 150 years, so its presence in the surrounding neighborhoods cannot be boiled down to a single anecdote. It has been there for births and deaths and the large and small crises in between: a case of a school principal with whooping
title: DISPATCHES; A Hospital That's Critical, As Neighbors Pace and Fret

body: The State Health Department has promised a loan to a community hospital in Brooklyn's Cobble Hill neighborhood to help it keep its obstetric and pediatric services operating, but hospital officials said Tuesday that more money would be needed to keep the services running beyond the end of the year. In a letter sent late Monday to Long Island
title: State Tries to Save Obstetrics At a Hospital in Brooklyn

body: FOR CHILDREN AMERICAN BALLET THEATER'S HEALTHY DANCER OPEN HOUSE (Sunday) You don't have to be a member of the company to dance through the doors of American Ballet Theater's studios on Sunday. title: Spare Times

body: FOR CHILDREN GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM'S FALL FAMILY DAY You don't expect to find a rain forest right around the bend, at least not in Manhattan. But on Sunday children will explore such a place in their own urban jungle, the bend being one of the many curves in the spiraling ramp of the Guggenheim Museum. title: Spare Times: For Children

body: AROUND TOWN 'I AM A MAN' You've heard this already, but it bears repeating: 40 years after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, Barack Obama became the first African-American to be elected president of the United States. The dream of racial equality that Dr. King so eloquently described at the March on Washington has seemingly come
title: Spare Times

body: New York City's antiquated voting system buckled, groaned and occasionally even gave way on Tuesday as millions of people thronged the polls to cast votes in the presidential election. Persistent problems from past elections -- broken machines, long waits and confusion among poll workers -- were made even worse, voters and election observers said,
title: Big Turnout Means Lines For Voters Across City

body: THE NEW MILLENNIUM PAPER AIRPLANE CONTEST When planes take off from Queens, it isn't exactly newsworthy. But the dozens of aircraft that will fly in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park on Saturday won't be the typical Boeings and Airbuses. They won't have engines, passengers or pilots, and they may travel only a matter of feet. Still, they are designed to
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: THE first thing you notice about Char No. 4, the new bourbon-obsessed bar in Cobble Hill, is the intimidating wall of whiskey sitting directly behind the bartender and stretching up to the ceiling. More than a hundred bottles are displayed in a custom-designed iron and walnut case, and a muted backlight suffuses the young professionals at the bar
title: BOîTE; A Straight-Up Kind of Place

body: CFA-IAMS CAT CHAMPIONSHIP This weekend both Barack Obama and John McCain will appear at Madison Square Garden. They won't debate, give speeches or sign autographs, and they may not even make eye contact. Any expressed hostilities are likely to be, well, catty. That's because this Obama and this McCain are cats. Barack Obama, a Bombay, and John
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: THOUGH New Yorkers were recently brought up short by the financial crisis, with no one quite knowing just how bad it would be, one thing this city has going for it is its resiliency. Yes, there are worries about 401(k)s and mortgage payments -- and perhaps a second thought about spending time in clubs with $300 bottle service -- but there are still
title: 36 Hours: New York City

author: E-mail: streetscapes@nytimes.com
body: BUILT in 1879 as a group of model tenements, the Tower Buildings, at Hicks and Baltic Streets in Cobble Hill, were rescued in the 1970s by Frank Farella, a local developer who for years kept the Brooklyn complex as a low-rent paradise. Now Mr. Farella has taken on a partner, the Hudson Companies, and their collaboration may bring substantial
title: STREETSCAPES | TOWER BUILDINGS IN BROOKLYN; Architectural Wealth, Built for the Poor

body: They are angling for the magic number: 26. That is how many City Council members it would take to defeat a bill introduced on Tuesday, at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's request, to change the city's term limits law. On Wednesday, they took to the streets -- a band of volunteers and organizers with the Working Families Party, which is spearheading a
title: Fighting Bid to Extend Term Limits, Politician by Politician

body: For the past year, New Yorkers have largely felt apart from the economic turmoil enveloping other parts of the country. But businesses in and around the city have reason to fret, now that banks are becoming more tightfisted during the deepening crisis in credit markets worldwide. Small businesses often live at the mercy of their creditors. When
title: Even Healthy Retailers Fear Loss of Credit Lifeline

body: FOR CHILDREN 'THE GREEN SHEEP' If you took a toddler to the theater, you'd probably expect more drama in the audience than onstage. title: Spare Times: For Children

title: Spare Times

title: Spare Times: For Children

title: For Children

body: On the campaign trail, in boardrooms and around kitchen tables nationwide, much of the talk about the economy is dire. Homeowners are facing foreclosure, major banks have failed and Wall Street has laid off thousands of workers. In Albany, Gov. David A. Paterson has invoked the Great Depression in warning about the severity of the recession he says
title: City Feels the Economic Pinch, but It's Only a Pinch, So Far

body: At first glance the stylized movements of the group of adults and teenagers attached to one another's wrists with long crepe ribbons seemed to be some kind of avant-garde twilight tai chi. title: Operatic Cargo of Tragic Love, Unloaded on a Brooklyn Pier

author: Compiled by Kris Ensminger E-mail: eating@nytimes.com
body: BoCoCa, a term coined several years ago for a shopping guide, refers to the junction of Boerum Hill, Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens. While it hasn't exactly caught on with the fervor of, say, TriBeCa or Dumbo, it does identify the site of a vibrant dining scene. These places have all opened in the past year or so. Black Mountain Wine House (718)
title: GOOD EATING | BOCOCA; Brooklyn Cornucopia

body: IT'S hard to miss the sprinkling of ''Hot Bird'' signs visible from Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. Aside from what could be considered the jarring juxtaposition of the words ''hot'' and ''bird,'' a few of the signs are painted a radiant yellow and are bigger than highway billboards. For more than a decade, the signs have made vegetarians wince and
title: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; On Teasing Walls, Traces of Roasters Past

body: AROUND TOWN SUMMER ON THE HUDSON For those of us who've paid little attention to the redevelopment of the Far West Side, Riverside Park South, the well-tended space beneath the West Side Highway near 70th Street, is often overshadowed by its far more developed counterparts. title: Spare Times

body: A minute into the third episode of ''The Line,'' a comedy about the passion and perversion of fans waiting 11 days for the premiere of a science-fiction film, the actor Joe Lo Truglio declares, ''I'm going line crazy.'' His partner, the ''Saturday Night Live'' repertory player Bill Hader, promises to get water. Then the ''SNL'' writer and
title: A Summer Break of Comedy for the Web

author: Nathaniel Rich's first novel, ''The Mayor's Tongue,'' was published earlier this year.
body: NEW YORKERS may be prone to the flu in the winter, but in the summer the entire city comes down with a fever. Common symptoms include subway-platform fainting spells, air-conditioner sore throats, fits of sidewalk nudity, heat rash, heat migraines, heat confusion, heat rage and heat nightmares. Even the rats, lazily sampling the curb's all-night
title: His Blue Period

body: A community hospital in gentrifying Brooklyn is closing down its maternity ward and plans to sell the building that houses some of its obstetrical clinics and another building across the street. The hospital, Long Island College Hospital in Cobble Hill, delivered 2,800 babies -- an average of seven or eight a day -- in 2007, officials said,
title: Community Hospital in Brooklyn Is Closing Maternity Ward and Selling the Space

body: To the Editor: Re ''Restless Pioneers, Seeding Brooklyn,'' July 16: I have lived in the Carroll Gardens, Cobble Hill, Boerum Hill neighborhood (sorry, I refuse to call it Bococa) for 23 years. We used to have to travel to Park Slope or Bay Ridge to find something okayish to eat. Since Jim Mamary and Alan Harding opened Patois and began the Smith
title: Brooklyn Pioneers

body: It is easy to forget, in celebrating the suspension of street-cleaning parking rules, that such an act is accompanied by the suspension of, well, street cleaning. The absence of those lumbering scritchy-scratch street sweepers has not gone unnoticed in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where a two-month hiatus from alternate-side parking rules has created an
title: Parking Rules Return; Cleaner Streets to Follow

body: I WAS late to ''Rent.'' Late to the show, and late to the city it portrays. When I arrived in New York, in the fall of 1998, bistros and boutiques had already infiltrated the East Village, gentrification was spreading into the Lower East Side, and northwest Brooklyn had largely fallen to the forces of the bourgeoisie. ''Rent'' had already been
title: Bohemia Takes Its Final Bows

body: It may have been a sapling, but it looked like a stick. Diane Dillon, for one, was fairly skeptical that the branch her elderly neighbor stuck in the ground in front of his Cobble Hill brownstone one day in the late 1960s -- a twig, no thicker than her finger -- would ever amount to much. She was pretty sure the wind would just blow it away. But
title: COBBLE HILL JOURNAL; A Sapling Grows Into a Giant; The Streets Around It Change, Too

body: INTERNATIONAL ISRAEL AND HAMAS CALL A TRUCE, But Some Ask if It Can Last The cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, went into effect just as the sun was rising over Sderot, an Israeli border town plagued by rocket fire from Gaza for the past seven years. The truce holds, in theory, the possibility of a new era in
title: INSIDE THE TIMES: June 20, 2008

body: FOR CHILDREN 'TAKE ME OUT TO THE BALL GAME: 1864' The games New Yorkers play may be infinite, but at least those on athletic fields are usually identifiable. title: Spare Times: For Children

title: For Children

body: For working stiffs, the fun in the sun ended on Monday. After two days of toying with the stifling weather in shorts and T-shirts, they found the most mundane chores a challenge during record-high temperatures in the New York region. The early-season swelter created an array of problems, from power failures to delays on several subway lines.
title: In a Sweltering City, Any Sliver of Shade Will Do

body: Doctors at a community hospital in Brooklyn that is part of a large system of hospitals say they are being squeezed out so the system can sell off property in popular neighborhoods. The doctors contend that the parent company, Continuum Health Partners, has been downsizing the institution where they work, Long Island College Hospital, in the Cobble
title: Doctors Say Hospital Is Falling Victim to Its Own Real Estate Value

body: NEW PLACES The Moxie Spot 81-83 Atlantic Avenue, Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 923-9710 With the seemingly relentless rise in both the quality of Brooklyn restaurants and the number of strollers on the streets, it makes sense that someone finally opened a restaurant that tries to merge the two. title: DINING BRIEFS

title: For People With Down Syndrome, Longer Life Has Complications

body: If you will excuse a biblical flourish, the G train is the Moses of New York mass transit. Like Moses, it never made it to the Promised Land. title: NYC; Rallying Round a Train That Gets No Respect

title: Spare Times: For Children

body: To the Editor: ''In City's Growing Neighborhoods, Public Schools Face Pupil Jam'' (front page, May 9) describes the latest twist in New York City's school facilities crisis. In 1988 the New York State Legislature, before creating the School Construction Authority, found that ''many of the schools are overcrowded, unsafe, unhealthy and unusable.''
title: LETTERS; The Woes of New York's Public Schools

body: EVIDENCE suggests that New Yorkers may be more religiously observant now than three decades ago. The number of churches, temples, mosques and other houses of worship -- many of them in storefronts -- jumped by 37 percent in Manhattan from 1980 to 2000, according to census data. In Brooklyn during the same period, the jump was a whopping 87 percent.
title: POSTING; Brooklyn Churches Come and Go

title: Spare Times

title: Developers Picked for 2 Closed Brooklyn Firehouses

body: THE faintest glimmer of an economic slowdown is on the horizon this summer in some of the most popular vacation spots within a two-hour drive of New York. title: Wiggle Room

body: The last few re-election races have not been particularly easy ones for Representative Edolphus Towns, a 13-term incumbent from central Brooklyn. And now he is preparing again to face a challenge for the Democratic nomination
title: Brooklyn Congressman and Veteran Of Tough Primaries Faces New Fight

body: DEAR DIARY: My 11-year-old son, Simon, had agreed to call me during his school lunch and let me know if he was coming home by himself or with a friend. Much to my surprise, he wrote me from his computer class at school while I was working at my desk computer. It perfectly represents where we are in our relationship at his age, when ''cool rules''
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: AFTER nearly a quarter-century of removing stains, pressing suits and altering dresses in a storefront on Court Street in Cobble Hill, the dry cleaners known around the neighborhood as Mr. and Mrs. Oh closed the doors of their shop, Trusting Cleaners, for the last time on March 15. title: COBBLE HILL; A Fabric Of Life Loses a Thread That Binds

body: MALOTT--Mary Myart, also known as Mary McIntyre: 1928-2008. Mary was an Austin, Texas and New York City painter, sculptor, assemblage artist, art critic, and diarist whose artistic bent also led her into unpredicted success in real estate development. author: Nathaniel Rich, an editor at The Paris Review, is the author of ''The Mayor's Tongue,'' a novel to be published by Riverhead Books in April.
body: I RECENTLY went into Manhattan with a friend to visit her younger brother's new apartment on 52nd Street and the East River. The brother, Ariel, had just graduated from college and had been hired by a prestigious financial firm in Midtown. His two roommates had followed the same path, and so, apparently, had everyone else who lived on their long,
title: His City, Lost and Found

body: WHEN Julia Warr, Martin Brierley and their three children moved to Brooklyn from London two and a half years ago, they settled in Cobble Hill, largely because of the local elementary school, Public School 29. So it was with some chagrin that they found out not long ago, on a visit to a friend's place, that they were smitten with the friend's
title: LIVING IN | SOUTH WILLIAMSBURG, BROOKLYN; Still a Warehouse Wonderland

body: WALKING along Adelphi Street in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, you could almost miss The Hideout, and not just because the former parking garage doesn't have a sign. No Jimmy Choo-shilling boutiques or coolly antiseptic hotels indicate to scene-seekers that behind those black curtains and nondescript doors is a sexy little lounge offering $14 cocktails --
title: BOÎTE; Small and Sexy

body: MALOTT--Mary, Myart also known as Mary McIntyre: 1928-2008. Mary was an Austin, Texas and New York City painter, sculptor, assemblage artist, art critic, and diarist whose artistic bent also led her into unpredicted success in real estate development. She died January 21, 2008, at the age of 79 at the Cobble Hill Nursing Home in Brooklyn, NY after
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MALOTT, MARY

title: Spare Times

body: Christine Agro's career as a pet psychic to the stars started, as so many auspicious events do, with a particularly open chakra. The chakra in question did not belong to her, but to a young woman who happened to pop into one of Ms. Agro's yoga classes in upstate New York five years ago, and thanked her at the end of class for freeing up that center
title: BIG CITY; Psychic Tends To the Famous, And Their Pets

body: A TOP-FLOOR apartment was what Michelle Panzer and Paul Campbell wanted most. They craved the quiet that came with having no inconsiderate neighbors tromping above them. Tomblike silence was their ideal. To avoid noise, they would have been happy with ''a crypt -- an apartment buried underground,'' Ms. Panzer said. But at the same time, they wanted
title: THE HUNT; Quiet on the Home Front
